Carbon nanofibers decorated with oxo–rhenium complexes: Highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for oxidation of amines with hydrogen peroxide Sanny Verma a Subodh Kumar a Efrat Shawat b Gilbert Daniel Nessim b Suman L. Jain a ⁎ a Chemical Sciences Division, CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum, Dehradun 248005, India Chemical Sciences Division CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum Dehradun 248005 India b Department of Chemistry, Bar Ilan Institute for Nanotechnology and Advanced materials (BINA), Bar Ilan University, Ramat Gan 52900, Israel Department of Chemistry Bar Ilan Institute for Nanotechnology and Advanced materials (BINA) Bar Ilan University Ramat Gan 52900 Israel ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 135 2525788; fax: +91 135 2660202. Graphical abstract Pyridine functionalized carbon nanofibers (Py-CNFs) were synthesized, characterized and used for the grafting of oxo–rhenium complex i.e., methyltrioxorhenium (MTO) via acid-base ionic interaction. The grafting of MTO to Py-CNFs was confirmed by FTIR, UV–vis, SEM, TEM and TGA analyses. The determination of rhenium content by ICP-AES further suggested the successful immobilization of MTO to the support. The developed heterogeneous material i.e., MTO@Py-CNFs was found to be an efficient catalyst for the oxidation of various secondary as well as tertiary amines to corresponding nitrones or N-oxides, respectively by using hydrogen peroxide. The developed catalyst was readily recovered by centrifugation and reused for subsequent ten runs without any significant loss in catalytic activity. Keywords Carbon nanofibers Heterogeneous catalyst Oxidation Amine Methyltrioxorhenium 1 Introduction The carbon cluster-based materials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and carbon nanofibers (CNFs) have received considerable interest in recent years owing to their unique structure and inherent physical, chemical, electronic and mechanical properties [1,2]. Since 1991 [3], carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been established as a new class of nanomaterials and are being used for various applications including in batteries, hydrogen storage, gas sensors, optoelectronic devices and catalytic applications [4–6]. Carbon nanofibers have also gained significant attention given that they are easier to synthesize and have shown potential for many applications [6]. In recent years, great interest is being paid toward the development of versatile chemical modification methodologies to obtain carbon nanostructure derivatives with more attractive features [7,8]. In this regard, a number of derivatives have been prepared and fully characterized that exhibit promising applications in nano-biotechnology and catalysis [9–10]. Owing to the growing environmental and economical considerations, the recycling of catalysts has become a prime need in the area of catalysis. One logical approach to address this concern is the immobilization of catalysts onto solid supports like organic polymers, nanoparticles or porous inorganic materials in order to recycle the catalyst [11,12]. Owing to their high surface area, extreme thermal stability and the tailorable shape and surface properties, carbon nanostructures can be served as supports for catalysts [13,14]. Most of the applications aim for carbon materials as a support for metallic nanoparticles, particularly palladium on charcoal [15]. Nevertheless, in the last decade, an increasing interest is grown toward the chemical functionalization and the immobilization of molecular catalysts onto carbon supports [16–19]. CNTs or CNFs can be modified by two ways: (1) covalent modification, (2) organic non covalent modification [20]. Covalent modification is an important tool for introducing new functional groups and this can be accomplished by the oxidation of defect sites and subsequent conversion in to derivatives such as amide, aryl diazonium salt addition, cycloaddition etc. [21–25]. After covalent modification, the modified carbon nanostructures are subjected to the metal complexes, forming heterogeneous high performance nanocatalytic materials for various applications including catalysis. Methyltrioxorhenium(VII) (MTO) described by Hermann et al. about 23 years ago as the first organometallic rhenium oxide, is a homogeneous catalyst which has extensively been used for various organic transformations such as in oxidation reactions (epoxidation of olefins, Bayer-Villiger oxidation, oxidation of alcohols, oxidation of amines), in Diels–Alders reactions and in the metathesis of olefins [26–28]. However the difficult recovery and non-recycling ability of the catalyst restricts its utility from industrial viewpoints. Subsequently, heterogenization of MTO to various solid supports has come out to be a promising approach in order to make it easily recoverable and recyclable [29–32]. In 2007 a review on MTO heterogenization on different supports was carried out, and since then only few reports are published in this area [33]. Very recently, we have reported the immobilization of MTO to chemically functionalized graphene oxide and its subsequent use for oxidation of secondary amines to nitrones [34]. However the multi-step synthetic procedure of immobilization, higher reaction temperature and longer reaction times were the main drawbacks of the reported method. In continuation to our efforts toward improving the methodology, herein we report the immobilization of oxo–rhenium complex i.e., methyl trioxo-rhenium to chemically functionalized carbon nanofibers and their subsequent use for the oxidation of secondary and tertiary amines with hydrogen peroxide (Scheme 1 ). The carbon nanofibers were extracted from carbon nanofiber mats. The synthesis of the CNF mats is described in our recent literature report [35]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Techniques used The XRD pattern was collected using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at 40kV and 40mA with Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15418nm). Sample was evenly spread on glass slide and analyzed after drying well. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis of sample in KBr pallets was conducted by PerkinElmer Spectrum RX-1 IR spectrophotometer. Absorption spectra(UV–vis) of Py-CNFs and MTO@ Py-CNFs were collected in water with a PerkinElmer lambda-19 UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer using a 10mm quartz cell. Morphology and EDX of catalyst was determined using Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) Jeol Model JSM-6340F. For SEM analysis aqueous dispersion of samples were deposited on glass slide. Transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images with EDX data of MTO@Py-CNFs on carbon coated copper grid was extracted using FEI-TecnaiG2 Twin TEM operating at an acceleration voltage of 200kV. Thermo gravimetric analyses (DT-TGA) curve for determining thermal stability of catalyst was plotted using a thermal analyzer TA-SDT Q-600 from 30 to 550°C with heating rate of 10°C/min under the nitrogen flow. Rhenium wt% in catalyst was calculated using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, DRE, PS-3000UV, Leeman Labs Inc., USA). 0.01g of sample was digested in minimum amount of conc. HNO3 with heating, and volume made up to 10ml. The conversions and selectivity of the products were determined by high resolution GCMSD, EI, quadrapole mass analyzer, EM detector. 2.2 Synthesis of Py-CNFs The synthesis of pyridine-functionalized carbon nanofibers (Py-CNFs) was carried out by following the literature procedure [36]. In a typical experiment, 0.5g of NaNO2 was dissolved in 1mL H2O, and then cooled to 0°C by ice bath. 0.7g of 4-aminopyridine (4-AP) was dissolved in 0.5mL 4M HCl, and then cooled to 0°C by ice bath. The solution of NaNO2 was added drop wise to 4-AP solution. The resulting yellow solution was maintained at 0°C in ice bath and stirred for 30min. CNFs were purified before use by being immersed in conc. HCl solution for 5 days and then refluxed for 5h, followed by thoroughly washing with water and acetone. The purified CNFs were dried at 80°C under vacuum for 12h. 10mg of purified CNFs were dispersed in a 15mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) using a sonicator bath for 2h. The CNF solution was cooled to 0°C by ice bath, and then the yellow solution of NaNO2 and 4-AP was added drop wise, maintained at 0°C to prevent the decomposition of diazonium salts. The resulting mixture was kept at room temperature under stirring for 20h. The resulting pyridyl functionalized CNFs (Py-CNFs) were collected by filtration and then thoroughly washed with 2M HCl, 2M NaOH, water, acetone and then dried at 80°C under vacuum for 12h. 2.3 Immobilization of MTO to Py-CNFs [31,37] Py-CNFs (10mg) were dispersed in 50mL dry tetrahydrofuran (THF) using a bath sonicator for 2h. A solution of methyltrioxorhenium (MTO; 2.5mg) in THF (5mL) was added to the above prepared suspension of CNFs and stirred the resulting mixture for 3h under argon atmosphere. The resulting product of MTO@Py-CNF was collected by centrifugation, thoroughly washed with THF, methanol and acetone and finally dried under vacuum for 6h at 50°C. 2.4 Typical experimental procedure for oxidation of amines A 25mL round bottomed flask was charged sequentially with catalyst (1.0mol %), CH3OH (2mL), 50wt% aq. H2O2 (1.5mmol) and then stirred at room temperature for 10min. Diethylamine (1mmol) was added to the reaction mixture and then stirred the resulting mixture at room temperature. The progress of the reaction with time was monitored by thin layer chromatography (SiO2). At the end of the reaction the catalyst was filtered over membrane filter paper and reused for subsequent runs. The filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure. Organic layer was extracted with CH2Cl2 and dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate. The product was purified by column chromatography over silica gel. Conversion of the product was determined by the GC–MS analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the catalyst To achieve the objective of the present work, chemical functionalization of the carbon nanofibers was carried out by using the diazonium reaction to graft the pyridyl moieties at the surface of carbon nanofibers. Thus obtained Py-CNFs were dispersed in dry THF and then treated with MTO in dry THF to obtain heterogeneous catalyst i.e., MTO supported to pyridyl-functionalized carbon nanofibers (MTO@Py–CNFs) through the ionic interaction between rhenium center of MTO and nitrogen of pyridine in CNF’s as shown in Scheme 2 . The rhenium metal content in the synthesized heterogeneous material was determined by ICP-AES analysis and was found to be 1.4wt% (0.07mmol/g). 3.1.1 FTIR The chemical changes occurred during the immobilization of MTO on CNFs were monitored by FTIR (Fig. 1 ). As shown in Fig. 1a, the vibrational peaks with strong intensity at 3428 and 1632cm−1 attributed to the stretching modes of OH and CC bond, respectively in carbon nanofibers. Subsequent, attachment of 4-amino pyridine with CNFs (Py-CNF) via diazotization reaction was confirmed by appearance of new vibrational bands i.e., (a) at 1442cm−1 corresponding to NN and (b) in the region of 1650–1570cm−1 related to the CC and CN of pyridine ring (Fig. 1b). In case of MTO@Py–CNF (Fig. 1c) a characteristic band at 906cm−1 corresponding to the ReO asymmetric stretching, confirmed the successful immobilization of MTO to the support. 3.1.2 XRD The XRD pattern of the synthesized MTO@Py-CNF as shown in Fig. 2 clearly indicated that the synthesized material was crystalline in nature. The diffraction peaks at 2θ =27.79°, 41.98°, 54.86° and 77.12° are indicating the hexagonal graphite structure of the CNFs. 3.1.3 TEM The TEM analysis of synthesized MTO@Py-CNF shows a homogeneous distribution of MTO throughout the surface of CNF (Fig. 3 ). Appearance of black spots in Fig. 3a and c suggesting the successful grafting of MTO molecules to the chemically functionalized CNF support. Furthermore, EDX analysis clearly indicated the presence of rhenium in the synthesized material (Fig. 3d). 3.1.4 UV–vis Furthermore, we analyzed the synthesized pyridyl functionalized carbon nanofibers (Py-CNF), and MTO supported CNF (MTO@Py-CNF) by UV–vis spectroscopy (Fig. 4 ). The pyridine functionalized CNFs (Py-CNF) show characteristic absorption at ∼220nm owing to the discrete units of sp2 bonded carbons (π–π*) (Fig. 4a). However, this peak at 220nm in Py–CNF was shifted to 226nm in MTO@Py-CNF revealing the attachment of MTO molecules to support matrix. Furthermore, the presence of n–π* also support the loading of MTO catalyst on the MTO–Py-CNF (Fig. 4b). 3.1.5 TGA The thermal decomposition behavior of Py–CNF and MTO@Py–CNF catalyst was examined by thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 5 ). In case of Py–CNFs, the major weight loss is observed in the range of 170–260°C, due to thermal decomposition of functionalized pyridine moieties (Fig. 5a). However, MTO@Py-CNF catalyst shows a different weight loss pattern than the pyridyl functionalized CNFs. It is well reported that the MTO sublimes below 100°C, thus we presumed that the initial weight loss (3–4%) in MTO@Py-CNF up to 100°C is owing to the decomposition/sublimation of MTO. Further weight loss is in the range of 160–270°C attributed to the decomposition of the pyridyl moieties. Then, the major mass loss in the range of 350–550°C is attributed to the decomposition of the carbon backbone. Furthermore, the ICP-AES analysis of the synthesized heterogeneous MTO@Py-CNF revealed 1.4wt % rhenium (0.07mmol/g) in the prepared catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the synthesized heterogeneous catalyst i.e., MTO@Py-CNF was tested for the oxidation of various secondary and tertiary amines including aliphatic, aromatic and heterocyclic to the corresponding nitrones or N-oxides respectively by using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant and methanol as solvent at room temperature (Scheme 1). At first, the oxidation of diethylamine was carried out in the absence of catalyst. The reaction did not take place even after prolonged reaction time (24h) in the absence of catalyst (Table 1 , entry 1). However, in the presence of catalyst (1mol %), the oxidation of diethyl amine occurred efficiently and gave 90% conversion within 3h. Further, the effect of various solvents was investigated for the oxidation of diethylamine under described experimental conditions. Among the various solvents such as methanol, dichloromethane, benzene and acetonitrile studied, methanol was found to be best and provided the highest product yield. To evaluate the effect of catalyst amount, the oxidation of dibenzylamine was performed by varying the amount of catalyst from 0.5 to 2.0mol %. The reaction was found to increase initially with increasing the catalyst amount (Table 1, entry 1). However, further increase in catalyst concentration from 1 to 1.5 and 2.0mol % did not give any significant improvement in the yield of the desired product (Table 1, entry 1). Thus, we have considered the 1.0mol % as the optimum catalyst amount for this transformation. The reaction was found to occur efficiently at room temperature and higher reaction temperatures (50°C) did not influence the reaction to any significant extent. Thus, the optimized reaction conditions for the present reaction are: substrate (1mmol), hydrogen peroxide (1.5mmol), catalyst (1.0mol %), and methanol (2mL) at room temperature. The reaction was extended to a variety of secondary and tertiary amines under the optimized reaction conditions. The results of these experiments are summarized in Table 1. In general, secondary amines (Table 1, entries 1–11) were found to be less reactive than tertiary amines (Table 1, entries 10–13). The recycling of the MTO@Py–CNF catalyst was examined by selecting the oxidation of diethylamine as a model reaction under optimized conditions. After completion of the reaction as monitored by TLC (SiO2), the catalyst was easily separated by simple filtration, washed with methanol and dried under vacuum for 8h. The recovered catalyst was subsequently used for the recycling experiments. The recovered catalyst showed consistent activity up to six runs which was marginally decreased for the subsequent runs as shown in Fig. 6 . The possible reason for decrease in activity after sixth run might be due to the slower decomposition of the oxo–rhenium to inactive perrhenate species in the presence of aqueous hydrogen peroxide [40]. The catalyst did not show any detectable leaching of metal as confirmed by ICP-AES. The rhenium content in the recovered catalyst after tenth run was found to be 1.36wt%, which was nearly similar to the fresh catalyst (1.4wt%). The developed heterogeneous catalyst was found to be superior to the existing supported catalysts. For example oxidation of diethylamine with H2O2 in the presence of tungstate-exchanged Mg–Al layered double hydroxide provided 60% yield of nitrone in 5h [38]. The oxidation of benzaldehyde and benzylamine using UHP as oxidant using Nafion immobilized MoOCl2 as catalyst afforded 65% yield of the phenyl benzyl nitrone in 4.5h [39]. Similarly, the oxidation of diethyl amine using graphene oxide immobilized MTO as catalyst afforded 85% yield of corresponding nitrone in 8h [34]. In order to prove the identity of MTO in grafted catalyst and formation of active peroxo-species during the reaction we performed the blank experiment by using excess of oxidant hydrogen peroxide (5 eq) and catalyst (1 eq). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2h and then the catalyst was recovered and analyzed by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 7 ). Raman spectrum clearly shows the characteristic bands of a Re-peroxo moiety, found at 509, 452 and 977cm−1 (Fig. 7). In addition, the Re(O)2 vibrational bands at 917 and 885cm−1 are still visible, indicating the formation of a mono-peroxo complex. Furthermore, absence of characteristic OH bands of perrhenate anion (ReOH bands) at 998, 995, 556 and 538cm−1 in Raman spectra of MTO@Py-CNF/H2O2 catalyst was in analogy to the existing literature [40] that confirm the formation of active mono peroxo-intermediate species during the reaction. Furthermore, these results indicated that MTO was stable during the immobilization and the grafted moiety was MTO not dissociated perrhenate anion. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have reported for the first time the use of chemically functionalized carbon nanofibers as the support for the grafting of methyltrioxorhenium catalyst. Pyridine ligands on CNFs led to the enduring and uniform loading of MTO on the support. The developed heterogeneous material was found to be an efficient and highly reactive catalyst for the oxidation of various secondary and tertiary amines to the nitrones and N-oxides respectively by using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant at room temperature. The catalyst was easily recovered at the end of the reaction and recycled for several runs without any remarkable loss in catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Pyridine functionalized carbon nanofibers (Py-CNFs) were synthesized, characterized and used for the grafting of oxo–rhenium complex i.e., methyltrioxorhenium (MTO) via acid-base ionic interaction. The grafting of MTO to Py-CNFs was confirmed by FTIR, UV–vis, SEM, TEM and TGA analyses. The determination of rhenium content by ICP-AES further suggested the successful immobilization of MTO to the support. The developed heterogeneous material i.e., MTO@Py-CNFs was found to be an efficient catalyst for the oxidation of various secondary as well as tertiary amines to corresponding nitrones or N-oxides, respectively by using hydrogen peroxide. The developed catalyst was readily recovered by centrifugation and reused for subsequent ten runs without any significant loss in catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Carbon nanofibers decorated with oxo–rhenium complexes: Highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for oxidation of amines with hydrogen peroxide
